Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Intelligent Restoration System for a Self-healing Smart Grid (IRS-SG)

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
How can we restore power more effectively after a major outage, such as a hurricane, a cascade blackout or a more local outage? Can we use modern computer-based methods to get better performance than what we have today, in a system which is mainly informal and based on guesswork under conditions of great stress and limited information? This new collaborative project will bring together an expert on power restoration with a pioneer of new intelligent computation methods for the power grid, in hopes of finding a more powerful and modern way to restore power more effectively. The goals are; (1) to develop an online adaptive restoration tool using advanced scalable computational intelligence techniques; (2) investigate a novel scheme to use renewable resources in system restoration; (3) explore a blackstart unit investment strategy to improve the self-healing capability; and (4) real-time implementation and demonstration of the new system on benchmark and utility power systems. The grant will include travel to New Zealand, to discuss use of the new system to help provide better response to events like earthquakes. It will also include outreach to Native Americans in the Dakotas.

The problem of efficient restoration is very difficult from a technical point of view. A small number of researchers, like the lead PI, have developed a few tools of practical use in this problem, but it is still largely an unsolved problem. The main justification for NSF involvement in this area, and for significant hope of success, is the use of intelligent systems methods far beyond what anyone has applied in the past to this problem, methods pioneered in the intelligent systems part of the EPCN program at NSF
(described for example in the book Handbook of RLADP edited by Frank Lewis and Derong Liu). Data from new sources such as synchrophasors will be part of this work. The underlying algorithms are designed from the start to run on massively parallel
distributed systems, such as Cellular Neural Network hardware, which allow much faster real-time computation than traditional sequential computers and algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to create a self-healing electric power grid. We have accomplished the following achievements from this award:

1. An online adaptive restoration tool to assist the self-healing process

First, a two-stage adaptive decision support system has been developed for bulk power system restoration, including the comprehensive models of generation system start-up, transmission system energization, and load restoration. This tool determines restoration actions both in planning and real-time phases and adapts to constantly changing system conditions. 

To prevent large interconnected power system from a cascading failure, brownout or even blackout, grid operators require access to faster than real-time information to make appropriate just-in-time control decisions. The deployment of synchrophasor measurement devices makes it possible to capture and visualize, in near-real-time, grid operational data with extra granularity. In this project, a cellular computational network (CCN) approach for frequency situational intelligence (FSI) in a power system was developed. The distributed and scalable computing unit of the CCN framework makes it particularly flexible for customization for a particular set of prediction requirements.

 2. A new scheme to harness renewable and distributed energy resources in system restoration

First, a novel offline restoration planning tool for harnessing wind energy has been developed to provide the scheduled wind power at each restoration time, based on stochastic optimization models and two-stage decomposition techniques. Second, a novel coordination strategy of wind and pumped-storage hydro (PSH) units to accommodate wind power uncertainty and variability for a faster and reliable self-healing process. The two-stage adaptive robust optimization models and decomposition algorithms enables the coordinated wind and PSH units to increase the total energy served, enhance wind power dispatchability and reduce wind power curtailment. 

3. An optimal strategy to enhance the resilience of cyber-physical systems

The resilience of cyber-physical system, including power grid, communication system, and transportation system has been investigated. First, the recent development on the impact of extreme events on power system resilience has been reviewed, including the application of smart grid technologies to provide faster restoration techniques and enhance cyber-physical system resilience. Second, a survey has been delivered on utilizing social media as a platform to extract and analyze abstract data to produce intelligent information, which can be utilized to plan and implement resources towards power grid resiliency from micro level (consumers) to macro level (cities/states). New frameworks, approaches and algorithms have been developed for resilience of distributed energy system (DES) operations. These include for power systems operations including with Integration of renewable sources of energy. The situational intelligence and optimal control provides better anticipatory, preventative and restorative capabilities in control centers. The reliability of the power electronic interfaces (PEI), i.e. inverters is critical. Recent studies demonstrate enhanced operation of a PEI can be reached by optimum adjustment of its controller parameters. While conventional tuning methods are mostly based on trial and error, their optimum performance can be achieved for primarily first-order systems. For systems with increasing number of PEIs or more complexity, application of these tuning methods becomes challenging and expensive. Thus, considering the operational performance of DES, a controller self-tuning methodology was developed for PEIs with particle swarm optimization capability. 

 4. A testbed for real-time implementation of intelligent restoration system

The cyber-physical test bed have been developed at the Real-Time Power and Intelligent Systems (RTPIS) Laboratory at Clemson University. The UCF campus grid model is built in Siemens Microgrid Management System (MGMS) software. The historical PV data provided by Duke Energy has been used to generate live data in real-time simulation platform, OPAL-RT. The DNP3 protocol is used to connect different systems for testing developed restoration algorithms. The FSI systems were then implemented on two different scales of power systems at the RTPIS Lab, one of which installed a large photovoltaic plant. A real-time power system simulator with a weather station was then used to derive typical FSI for demonstration in a control center-like facility at RTPIS Lab.

New modules were added to existing graduate courses at Clemson. The developed testbed with real system model and data provides a platform for implementation and demonstration. It not only provides students hands-on experience, but also help train power professionals and engineers in recovering power grid from outages and blackouts.

This research has advanced the knowledge of operating power systems in emergency mode(s), opened the door to using renewable generators to assist and expedite the restoration process, and helped system planner make the long-run decisions of blackstart unit investment. The developed intelligent restoration system for a self-healing smart grid has made a great step towards building a self-healing smart grid.

The project outcomes include 1 book and 2 book chapter, 15 journal and 14 conference papers, 1 non-provisional patent, 30 invited talks and 10 organized panels at international conferences.
